cup: a small container that is like a bowl in shape, usually with a handle, used for drinking tea, coffee, etc.

DVD: an optical disk that can store a very large amount of digital data, as text, music, or images.

exist: to be real; to be present in a place or situation

exit: a way out of a public building or vehicle

experienced: having knowledge or skill in a particular job or activity
experiment: a scientific test that is done in order to study what happens and to gain new knowledge
expert: a person with special knowledge, skill or training in something

explanation: a statement, fact, or situation that tells you why something happened; a reason given for something
explode: to burst (= break apart) or make something burst loudly and violently, causing damage

explore: to travel to or around an area or a country in order to learn about it

export: the selling and transporting of goods to another country

express: to show or make known a feeling, an opinion, etc. by words, looks or actions
extend: to make something longer or larger

extra: more than is usual, expected, or than exists already

fail: to not be successful in achieving something

fancy: to want something or want to do something

fat: having too much flesh on it and weighing too much

fault: the responsibility for something wrong that has happened or been done
favor: something done or granted out of goodwill, rather than from justice or for remuneration; a kind act:
favorite: a person or thing regarded with special favor or preference:
fear: the bad feeling that you have when you are in danger or when a particular thing frightens you
feather: one of the many soft light parts covering a bird’s body
feature: something important, interesting or typical of a place or thing
February: the second month of the year, ordinarily containing 28 days, but containing 29 days in leap years. : Feb.

fee: an amount of money that you pay for professional advice or services

fellow: used to describe somebody who is the same as you in some way, or in the same situation
female: being a woman or a girl

fever: a medical condition in which a person has a temperature that is higher than normal
few: used with plural nouns and a plural verb to mean ‘a small number’, ‘some’
fiction: a type of literature that describes imaginary people and events, not real ones
field: an area of land in the country used for growing crops or keeping animals in, usually surrounded by a fence, etc.
fight: to take part in a war or battle against an enemy

fill: to make something full of something; to become full of something

finance: money used to run a business, an activity or a project
find: to discover somebody/something unexpectedly or by chance
finding: information that is discovered as the result of research into something
finger: one of the four long thin parts that stick out from the hand (or five, if the thumb is included)
finish: to stop doing something or making something because it is complete
fire: the flames, light and heat, and often smoke, that are produced when something burns
first: happening or coming before all other similar things or people; 1st

fit: to be the right shape and size for somebody/something
fitness: the state of being physically healthy and strong
fixed: staying the same; not changing or able to be changed

flame: a hot bright stream of burning gas that comes from something that is on fire
flash: a sudden bright light that shines for a moment and then disappears

flexible: able to change to suit new conditions or situations
flight: a journey made by air, especially in a plane
float: to move slowly on water or in the air
flood: a large amount of water covering an area that is usually dry
floor: the surface of a room that you walk on
flour: a fine white or brown powder made from grain, especially wheat, and used in cooking for making bread, cakes, etc.
flow: the steady and continuous movement of something/somebody in one direction
flower: the coloured part of a plant from which the seed or fruit develops. Flowers usually grow at the end of a stem and last only a short time.
flu: a serious disease caused by a virus, that causes a high temperature, severe pains and weakness
fly: to move through the air, using wings
focus: to give attention, effort, etc. to one particular subject, situation or person rather than another
fold: to bend something, especially paper or cloth, so that one part lies on top of another part
follow: to come or go after or behind somebody/something
following: that is/are going to be mentioned next
food: things that people or animals eat
foot: the lowest part of the leg, below the ankle, on which a person or an animal stands
football: a game played by two teams of 11 players, using a round ball that players kick up and down the playing field. Teams try to kick the ball into the other team’s goal.

force: violent physical action used to obtain or achieve something
foreign: in or from a country that is not your own
forest: a large area of land that is thickly covered with trees

form: a type or variety of something
formal: very correct and suitable for official or important occasions
forward: towards a place or position that is in front
found: to start something, such as an organization or an institution, especially by providing money

free: without particular plans or arrangements; not busy
freedom: the power or right to do or say what you want without anyone stopping you

frequency: the rate at which something happens or is repeated
fresh: recently produced or picked and not frozen, dried or preserved in tins or cans
Friday: the sixth day of the week, following Thursday.
friend: a person you know well and like, and who is not usually a member of your family
friendly: behaving in a kind and pleasant way because you like somebody or want to help them
frighten: to make somebody suddenly feel afraid

from: used to show where somebody/something starts
front: the part or side of something that faces forward; the side of something that you look at first
frozen: kept at a very low temperature in order to preserve it

fry: to cook something in hot fat or oil; to be cooked in hot fat or oil

full: containing or holding as much or as many as possible; having no empty space
fun: the feeling of enjoying yourself; activities that you enjoy
function: a special activity or purpose of a person or thing
fund: an amount of money that has been saved or has been made available for a particular purpose
fundamental: serious and very important; affecting the most central and important parts of something
fur: the soft thick mass of hair that grows on the body of some animals
furniture: objects that can be moved, such as tables, chairs and beds, that are put into a house or an office to make it suitable for living or working in

future: the time that will come after the present or the events that will happen then
gain: to obtain or win something, especially something that you need or want
gallery: a room or building for showing works of art, especially to the public
game: an activity that you do to have fun, often one that has rules and that you can win or lose; the equipment for a game

gather: to come together, or bring people together, in one place to form a group
general: affecting all or most people, places or things
generation: all the people who were born at about the same time

glass: a hard, usually clear, substance used, for example, for making windows and bottles
global: covering or affecting the whole world

goal: a frame with a net into which players must kick or hit the ball in order to score a point
god: the being or spirit that is worshipped and is believed to have created the universe
gold: a chemical element. Gold is a yellow precious metal used for making coins, jewellery, beautiful objects, etc.
golf: a game played over a large area of ground using sticks with a special shape to hit a small hard ball (a golf ball) into a series of 9 or 18 holes, using as few shots as possible
good: of high quality or an acceptable standard
goodbye: used when you are leaving somebody or when somebody else is leaving
goods: things that are produced to be sold
govern: to legally control a country or its people and be responsible for introducing new laws, organizing public services, etc.
government: the group of people who are responsible for controlling a country or a state
governor: a person who is the official head of a country or region that is governed by another country
grab: to take or hold somebody/something with your hand suddenly or roughly
grade: a mark given in an exam or for a piece of school work
gradually: slowly, over a long period of time
graduate: a person who has a university degree
grain: the small hard seeds of food plants such as wheat, rice, etc.; a single seed of such a plant
grandfather: the father of your father or mother
grandmother: the mother of your father or mother

grant: to agree to give somebody what they ask for, especially formal or legal permission to do something
grass: a common wild plant with narrow green leaves and stems that are eaten by cows, horses, sheep, etc.

gray: having the colour of smoke or ashes
green: having the colour of grass or the leaves of most plants and trees
greet: to say hello to somebody or to welcome them

ground: the solid surface of the earth
group: a number of people or things that are together in the same place or that are connected in some way
grow: to increase in size, number, strength or quality

gun: a weapon that is used for firing bullets or shells
gym: a room or hall with equipment for doing physical exercise, for example in a school

hair: the substance that looks like a mass of fine threads growing on a person's head

hall: a space or passage inside the entrance or front door of a building
hand: the part of the body at the end of the arm, including the fingers and thumb

happen: to take place, especially without being planned
happily: in a cheerful way; with feelings of pleasure
happiness: the state of feeling or showing pleasure
hard: difficult to do, understand or answer
hardly: almost no; almost not; almost none
harm: damage or injury that is caused by a person or an event
harmful: causing damage or injury to somebody/something, especially to a person’s health or to the environment
hat: a piece of clothing made to fit the head, often with a brim (= a flat edge that sticks out), usually worn out of doors
have: to own, hold or possess something
he: a male person or animal that has already been mentioned or is easily identified
headache: a continuous pain in the head

health: the condition of a person’s body or mind
healthy: having good health and not likely to become ill
hear: to be aware of sounds with your ears
heart: the organ in the chest that sends blood around the body, usually on the left in humans
heating: the process of supplying heat to a room or building; a system used to do this
heaven: the place believed to be the home of God where good people go when they die, sometimes imagined to be in the sky
heavily: to a great degree; in large amounts
heavy: weighing a lot; difficult to lift or move
heel: the back part of the foot below the ankle
height: the measurement of how tall a person or thing is

hell: the place believed to be the home of devils and where bad people go after death
hello: used as a greeting when you meet somebody, in an email, when you answer the phone or when you want to attract somebody’s attention
help: to make it easier or possible for somebody to do something by doing something for them or by giving them something that they need
helpful: able to improve a particular situation

herself: used when the woman or girl who performs an action is also affected by it

hey: used to attract somebody’s attention or to express interest, surprise or anger
hide: to put or keep somebody/something in a place where they/it cannot be seen or found
high: measuring a long distance from the bottom to the top
highlight: to emphasize something, especially so that people give it more attention
highway: a main road for travelling long distances, especially one connecting and going through cities and towns
hill: an area of land that is higher than the land around it, but not as high as a mountain
him: used as the object of a verb, after the verb be or after a preposition to refer to a male person or animal that has already been mentioned or is easily identified
himself: used when the man or boy who performs an action is also affected by it
his: of or belonging to a man or boy who has already been mentioned or is easily identified
historic: important in history; likely to be thought of as important at some time in the future
history: all the events that happened in the past
hit: to bring your hand, or an object you are holding, against somebody/something quickly and with force
hobby: an activity that you do for pleasure when you are not working

hold: to have somebody/something in your hand, arms, etc.
hole: a hollow space in something solid or in the surface of something
holiday: a period of time when you are not at work or school
hollow: having a hole or empty space inside
holy: connected with God or a particular religion
home: the house or flat that you live in, especially with your family
homework: work that is given by teachers for students to do at home
honest: always telling the truth, and never stealing or cheating
hope: to want something to happen and think that it is possible
horrible: very bad or unpleasant; used to describe something that you do not like
horror: a feeling of great shock or fear

host: a person who invites guests to a meal, a party, etc. or who has people staying at their house
hot: having a high temperature; producing heat

household: all the people living together in a house or flat
housing: houses, flats, etc. that people live in, especially when referring to their type, price or condition
however: used to introduce a statement that contrasts with something that has just been said
huge: extremely large in size or amount; great in degree
human: of or connected with people rather than animals, machines or gods

hungry: feeling that you want to eat something

hurricane: Alex Higgins (1949-2010) a British snooker player born in Belfast, Northern Ireland. He was the youngest ever winner of the world snooker championship in 1972 and went on to win again in 1982. He played his last tournament in 1997. He was given the name ‘Hurricane’ (= a violent storm) because of the speed at which he played. He was often in trouble with the authorities because of his violent behaviour.
hurry: to move or act quickly because there is not much time
hurt: to cause physical pain to somebody/yourself; to injure somebody/yourself
husband: the man that somebody is married to; a married man
I: the ninth letter of the English alphabet, a vowel.
ice: water that has frozen and become solid
idea: a plan, thought or suggestion, especially about what to do in a particular situation
identify: to recognize somebody/something and be able to say who or what they are
if: used to say that one thing can, will or might happen or be true, depending on another thing happening or being true
ignore: to pay no attention to something
ill: suffering from an illness or disease; not feeling well
illness: the state of being physically or mentally ill
illustrate: to use pictures, photographs, diagrams, etc. in a book, etc.
illustration: a drawing or picture in a book, magazine, for decoration or to explain something
image: a picture, photograph or statue that represents somebody/something
imaginary: existing only in your mind or imagination
imagination: the ability to create pictures in your mind; the part of your mind that does this
imagine: to form a picture in your mind of what something might be like
immigrant: a person who has come to live permanently in a different country from the one they were born in
impact: the powerful effect that something has on somebody/something
impatient: annoyed by somebody/something, especially because you have to wait for a long time
imply: to suggest that something is true or that you feel or think something, without saying so directly
import: a product or service that is brought into one country from another
important: having a great effect on people or things; of great value
impose: to introduce a new law, rule, tax, etc.; to order that a rule, punishment, etc. be used
impossible: that cannot exist or be done; not possible
impress: if a person or thing impresses you, you admire them or it

impressive: making you admire them, because they are very large, good, skilful, etc.
improve: to become better than before; to make something/somebody better than before
improvement: the act of making something better; the process of something becoming better
in: at a point within an area or a space
inch: a unit for measuring length or height, equal to 2.54 centimetres. There are 12 inches in a foot.
incident: something that happens, especially something unusual or unpleasant
include: if one thing includes another, it has the second thing as one of its parts
income: the money that a person, a region, a country, etc. earns from work, from investing money, from business, etc.
increase: to become greater in amount, number, value, etc.; to make something greater in amount, number, value, etc.
increasingly: more and more all the time
incredible: impossible or very difficult to believe
indeed: used after very and an adjective or adverb to emphasize a statement, description, etc.
indicate: to show that something is true or exists

individual: a person considered separately rather than as part of a group
indoor: located, done or used inside a building
industry: the production of goods from raw materials, especially in factories
infection: the act or process of causing or getting a disease
influence: the effect that somebody/something has on the way a person thinks or behaves or on the way that something works or develops
inform: to tell somebody about something, especially in an official way
informal: relaxed and friendly; not following strict rules of how to behave or do something
ingredient: one of the things from which something is made, especially one of the foods that are used together to make a particular dish
initiative: a new plan for dealing with a particular problem or for achieving a particular purpose
injure: to harm yourself or somebody else physically, especially in an accident
injury: harm done to a person’s or an animal’s body, for example in an accident
inner: inside; towards or close to the centre of a place
innocent: not guilty of a crime, etc.; not having done something wrong
inquiry: an official process to find out the cause of something or to find out information about something
insect: any small creature with six legs and a body divided into three parts. Insects usually also have wings. Ants, bees and flies are all insects.
inside: on or to the inner part of something/somebody; within something/somebody
insight: an understanding of what something is like
insist: to demand that something happen or that somebody agree to do something
inspire: to give somebody the desire, confidence or enthusiasm to do something well
install: to fix equipment or furniture into position so that it can be used
instance: a particular example or case of something
institute: an organization that has a particular purpose, especially one that is connected with education or a particular profession; the building used by this organization
institution: a large important organization that has a particular purpose, for example a university or bank
instruction: detailed information on how to do or use something
instructor: a person whose job is to teach somebody a practical skill or sport
instrument: an object used for producing musical sounds, for example a piano or a drum
insurance: an arrangement with a company in which you pay them regular amounts of money and they agree to pay the costs, for example, if you die or are ill, or if you lose or damage something
intelligence: the ability to learn, understand and think in a logical way about things; the ability to do this well
intelligent: good at learning, understanding and thinking in a logical way about things; showing this ability
intend: to have a plan, result or purpose in your mind when you do something
intended: that you are trying to achieve or reach
intention: what you intend or plan to do; your aim
interest: the feeling that you have when you want to know or learn more about somebody/something
interested: giving your attention to something because you enjoy finding out about it or doing it; showing interest in something and finding it exciting
interesting: attracting your attention because it is/they are special, exciting or unusual
internal: connected with the inside of something
international: connected with or involving two or more countries
internet: an international computer network connecting other networks and computers that allows people to share information around the world
interpret: to explain the meaning of something
interrupt: to say or do something that makes somebody stop what they are saying or doing
interview: a formal meeting at which somebody is asked questions to see if they are suitable for a particular job, or for a course of study at a college, university, etc.
into: to a position in or inside something
introduce: to tell two or more people who have not met before what each other’s names are; to tell somebody what your name is
introduction: the first part of a book or speech that gives a general idea of what is to follow
invent: to produce or design something that has not existed before
invention: a thing or an idea that has been invented
invest: to buy property, shares in a company, etc. in the hope of making a profit
investigate: to carefully examine the facts of a situation, an event, a crime, etc. to find out the truth about it or how it happened
investigation: an official examination of the facts about a situation, crime, etc.
investment: the act of investing money in something
invitation: a spoken or written request to somebody to do something or to go somewhere
invite: to ask somebody to come to a social event
involve: if a situation, an event or an activity involves something, that thing is an important or necessary part or result of it
involved: taking part in something; being part of something or connected with something
iron: a chemical element. Iron is a hard strong metal that is used to make steel and is also found in small quantities in blood and food.
island: a piece of land that is completely surrounded by water
issue: an important topic that people are discussing or arguing about
IT: (used to represent an inanimate thing understood, previously mentioned, about to be mentioned, or present in the immediate context):
it: used to refer to an animal or a thing that has already been mentioned or that is being talked about now
item: one thing on a list of things to buy, do, talk about, etc.
its: belonging to or connected with a thing, an animal or a baby
itself: used when the animal or thing that does an action is also affected by it
jacket: a piece of clothing worn on the top half of the body over a shirt, etc. that has arms and fastens down the front; a short, light coat
jam: a thick sweet substance made by boiling fruit with sugar, often sold in jars and spread on bread
January: the first month of the year, containing 31 days. : Jan.
jazz: a type of music with strong rhythms, in which the players often improvise (= make up the music as they are playing), originally created by African American musicians at the beginning of the 20th century
jeans: trousers made of denim (= a type of strong cotton)
jewelry: articles of gold, silver, precious stones, etc., for personal adornment.
job: work for which you receive regular payment
join: to fix or connect two or more things together
joke: something that you say or do to make people laugh, for example a funny story that you tell
journal: a newspaper or magazine that deals with a particular subject or profession
journalist: a person whose job is to collect and write news stories for newspapers, magazines, radio, television or online news sites
judge: a person in a court who has the authority to decide how criminals should be punished or to make legal decisions
judgment: an act or instance of judging.

To lose one parent, Mr Worthing, may be regarded as a misfortune; to lose both looks like carelessness.

In 1960 she married the photographer Tony Armstrong-Jones, who was later given the title of Lord Snowdon, but they were divorced in 1978. Their two children are David, Viscount Linley, and Lady Sarah Armstrong-Jones.

This was because the public was so keen for more Holmes stories.

usually: in the way that is usual or normal; most often
vacation: a period of time spent travelling or relaxing away from home
valley: an area of low land between hills or mountains, often with a river flowing through it; the land that a river flows through
value: how much something is worth in money or other goods for which it can be exchanged
van: (1934-2013) a US piano player of classical music. He first became famous in 1958 when he won the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, the first time it had been won by somebody who was not Russian.
variety: several different sorts of the same thing
vary: to be different from each other in size, shape, etc.
vast: extremely large in area, size, amount, etc.
vegetable: a plant or part of a plant that is eaten as food. Potatoes, beans and onions are all vegetables.
vehicle: a thing that is used for transporting people or goods from one place to another, such as a car or lorry
venue: a place where people meet for an organized event, for example a concert, sporting event or conference
version: a form of something that is slightly different from an earlier form or from other forms of the same thing
very: used before adjectives, adverbs and determiners to mean ‘in a high degree’ or ‘extremely’
victim: a person who has been attacked, injured or killed as the result of a crime, a disease, an accident, etc.
victory: success in a game, an election, a war, etc.
video: a system of recording moving pictures and sound, either using a digital method of storing data or (in the past) using videotape
view: what you can see from a particular place or position, especially beautiful countryside
viewer: a person watching television or a video on the internet
village: a very small town located in a country area
violence: violent behaviour that is intended to hurt or kill somebody
violent: involving or caused by physical force that is intended to hurt or kill somebody
virtual: made to appear to exist by the use of computer software, for example on the internet
virus: a living thing, too small to be seen without a microscope, that causes disease in people, animals and plants
vision: the ability to see; the area that you can see from a particular position
visit: to go to see a person or a place for a period of time
visitor: a person who visits a person or place
visual: of or connected with seeing or sight
vital: necessary or essential in order for something to succeed or exist
vitamin: a natural substance found in food that is an essential part of what humans and animals need to help them grow and stay healthy. There are many different vitamins.
voice: the sound or sounds produced through the mouth by a person speaking or singing
volume: the amount of space that an object or a substance fills; the amount of space that a container has
volunteer: a person who does a job without being paid for it
vote: a formal choice that you make in an election or at a meeting in order to choose somebody or decide something
wage: a regular amount of money that you earn, usually every week or every month, for work or services
wait: to stay where you are or delay doing something until somebody/something comes or something happens
waiter: a man whose job is to serve customers at their tables in a restaurant, etc.
wake: to stop sleeping; to make somebody stop sleeping
wall: a long, solid structure that rises straight up from the ground, made of stone, brick or concrete, that surrounds, divides or protects an area of land
want: to have a desire or a wish for something/somebody
war: a situation in which two or more countries or groups of people fight against each other over a period of time
warm: at a fairly high temperature in a way that is pleasant, rather than being hot or cold
warn: to tell somebody about something, especially something dangerous or unpleasant that is likely to happen, so that they can avoid it
warning: a statement, an event, etc. telling somebody that something bad or unpleasant may happen in the future so that they can try to avoid it
wash: to make something/somebody clean using water and usually soap
washing: the act of cleaning something using water and usually soap
waste: the act of using something in a careless or unnecessary way, causing it to be lost or destroyed
watch: to look at somebody/something for a time, paying attention to what happens
water: a liquid without colour, smell or taste that falls as rain, is in lakes, rivers and seas, and is used for drinking, washing, etc.
wave: a raised line of water that moves across the surface of the sea, ocean, etc.
way: a method, style or manner of doing something
we: I and another person or other people; I and you
wealth: a large amount of money, property, etc. that a person or country owns
wealthy: having a lot of money, possessions, etc.
weapon: an object such as a knife, gun, bomb, etc. that is used for fighting or attacking somebody
wear: to have something on your body as a piece of clothing, a decoration, etc.
weather: the condition of the atmosphere at a particular place and time, such as the temperature, and if there is wind, rain, sun, etc.
web: a system for finding information on the internet, in which documents are connected to other documents
website: a set of pages on the internet, where a company or an organization, or an individual person, puts information
wedding: a marriage ceremony, and the meal or party that usually follows it
Wednesday: the fourth day of the week, following Tuesday.
week: a period of seven days, either from Monday to Sunday or from Sunday to Saturday
weight: how heavy somebody/something is, which can be measured in, for example, kilograms or pounds
welcome: used as a greeting to tell somebody that you are pleased that they are there
well: in a good, right or acceptable way
west: the direction that you look towards to see the sun go down; one of the four main points of the compass
western: located in the west or facing west
wet: covered with or containing liquid, especially water
what: used in questions to ask for particular information about somebody/something
whatever: any or every; anything or everything
wheel: one of the round objects under a car, bicycle, bus, etc. that turns when it moves
when: at what time; on what occasion
whenever: at any time that; on any occasion that
where: in or to what place or situation
whereas: used to compare or contrast two facts
whether: used to express a doubt or choice between two possibilities
which: used in questions to ask somebody to be exact about one or more people or things from a limited number
while: during the time that something is happening; at the same time as something else is happening
whisper: to speak very quietly to somebody so that other people cannot hear what you are saying
white: having the colour of fresh snow or of milk
who: used in questions to ask about the name, identity or function of one or more people
whom: used instead of ‘who’ as the object of a verb or preposition
whose: used in questions to ask who something belongs to
why: used in questions to ask the reason for or purpose of something
wide: measuring a large distance from one side to the other
widely: by a lot of people; in or to many places
wife: the woman that somebody is married to; a married woman
wild: living or growing in natural conditions; not kept in a house or on a farm
wildlife: animals, birds, insects, etc. that are wild and live in a natural environment
win: to be the most successful in a competition, race, battle, etc.
window: an opening in the wall or roof of a building, car, etc., usually covered with glass, that allows light and air to come in and people to see out; the glass in a window
wine: an alcoholic drink made from the juice of grapes that has been left to ferment. There are many different kinds of wine.
wing: one of the parts of the body of a bird, insect or bat that it uses for flying
winner: a person, a team, an animal, etc. that wins something
winter: the coldest season of the year, between autumn and spring
wire: metal in the form of thin thread; a piece of this
wise: able to make sensible decisions and give good advice because of the experience and knowledge that you have
wish: to want something to happen or to be true even though it is unlikely or impossible
with: in the company or presence of somebody/something
within: before a particular period of time has passed; during a particular period of time
without: not having, experiencing or showing something
witness: a person who sees something happen and is able to describe it to other people
wonder: to think about something and try to decide what is true, what will happen, what you should do, etc.
wonderful: very good, pleasant or a lot of fun
wood: the hard material that the trunk and branches of a tree are made of; this material when it is used to build or make things with, or as a fuel
wool: the soft hair that covers the body of sheep and some other animals
word: a single unit of language that means something and can be spoken or written
work: to do something that involves physical or mental effort, especially as part of a job
worker: a person who works, especially one who does a particular kind of work
working: having a job for which you are paid
world: the earth, with all its countries, peoples and natural features
worldwide: affecting all parts of the world
worried: thinking about unpleasant things that have happened or that might happen and therefore feeling unhappy and afraid
worry: to keep thinking about unpleasant things that might happen or about problems that you have
worse: of poorer quality or lower standard; more unpleasant
worst: of the poorest quality or lowest standard; worse than any other person or thing of a similar kind
worth: having a value in money, etc.
would: used in polite offers or invitations
wound: an injury to part of the body, especially one in which a hole is made in the skin using a weapon
wow: used to show that you are very surprised or impressed by somebody/something
wrap: to cover something completely in paper or other material, for example when you are giving it as a present
write: to make letters or numbers on a surface, especially using a pen or a pencil
writer: a person whose job is writing books, stories, articles, etc.
writing: the activity of writing, in contrast to reading, speaking, etc.
written: expressed in writing rather than in speech
yard: a piece of land next to or around your house where you can grow flowers, fruit, vegetables, etc., usually with a lawn (= an area of grass)
year: the period from 1 January to 31 December, that is 365 or 366 days, divided into 12 months
yellow: having the colour of lemons or butter
yes: used to answer a question and say that something is correct or true
yet: used in negative sentences and questions to talk about something that has not happened but that you expect to happen
you: used as the subject or object of a verb or after a preposition to refer to the person or people being spoken or written to
young: having lived or existed for only a short time; not fully developed
your: of or belonging to the person or people being spoken or written to
yourself: used when the person or people being spoken to both cause and are affected by an action
youth: the time of life when a person is young, especially the time before a child becomes an adult
